title: Message to all players gold and lower
body:
I'm sorry for misguiding some of you in the past. I used to say elo hell wasnt real. That you just had to get better and you would make it out. I said this for years while i sat in plat comfortably enjoying the game. 

I now realize that i was wrong. Elo hell does exist and i fully admit that now. I realize now that the two years i spent in plat, I was never a better player  than anyone in gold, silver, or bronze. I was just lucky to have made it out on a winstreak in a place that had slightly more committed and sane players. 

5000 ranked games over the course of my 5 years playing the game. I'm stuck in silver and I have no hope of getting out. I got placed silver 3 after going 1-9 in placements and now over 200 ranked games later, i'm in silver 4. At no point, have I felt like i could contribute to my climb out. 

I maintained a 60% win ratio on my main champs back in the day, even when i play them and i get super fed it doesnt matter. its completely random who wins. i had no idea there were so many afks in this elo. i had no idea there were so many people feeding out of control that the game ends in 15 mins before mid game ever starts. 

So to all of you - I'm sorry. I didnt know it was so bad. And i'm sorry for ever telling you all you had to do was get better. I was wrong, you were right. You cant win here, its just luck who gets out and who doesnt, i finally can admit that. 

Hope you win the elo lotto,

Driz

**Edit:** I just wanted to say thanks to everyone on this post. If you are feeling  frustrated about your climb, I hope knowing that you aren't alone makes it a little easier on you - as it does for me. 

**Edit: ** Over 5,000 views wow! There is so much interesting discussion here, thank you everyone that has contributed your thoughts!

replies.body: Elo hell exists, and noone can deny that. The problem is with people who use it as an excuse to stop improving, thus becoming part of it themselves.

But to say you can't climb out of it is wrong.

I was once one of the "cant climb gg shit system cant carry these noobs" but learned to improve.

^ This.

More people need to realize that climbing isn't about how well you can carry a heavy team, it's about managing how heavy you are in the games you play. Being able to carry a team that's playing poorly helps, but you can lighten your load by avoiding being the heavy player that your team has to carry. Heavy players just don't climb.

If you don't take personal responsibility for your MMR, you're going to fixate on the games you did well and blame your heavy teammates for your loss, and you're going to disregard the games were you did poorly and blame your teammates for your shortcomings.

I disagree

I've been silver 2 every season since 4, and this year i got placed bronze 1 and one tricked Katarina and within 3 weeks of playing only about 100 games I'm already in my promos to silver 2 with almost every game I had on Kat I was capable of carrying almost every single game maintaining a 73% win rate across about 25 games.

No one can deny it? Lmfao, how about all the streamers who carry out of low elo with ease? How about the boosters? How about those of us on here who have gotten their smurf accounts up?

The only time I struggle in silver is when I haven't played there in awhile and have to change my mindset/playstyle. In plat I'd rely more on my teammates for help, after a couple games in silver I realize I have to take everything into my own hands, then I start winning a lot.

That's because those streamers are always **TIERS** higher to begin with, often times they'll be playing with a friend as well.

However the problem is if you're say, maybe a Silver 1 amongst silver 4s' then you'll have trouble climbing, at no point in time though will you be put against teams with higher overall skill ceilings to improve your play. Maybe that silver 1 will eventually become gold 3   level, but is still with silver 3s'. This is what ELO hell is, being stuck in a place where you cannot improve no matter how you try, it's all about hoping you get a good win streak to be chucked back on a stable path.

But heres the thing, streamers are NEVER in elo hell. Why? They'll do a few matches the MMR is noticeably higher and they get put on teams that are stacked in favor.

So Elo hell is essentially being stuck where you deserve to be? If you are close to your best ranking you should take a while to get there, thats how the system works and shows it is working correctly.

I like to think of "elo hell" as this awkward middle ground that's just above your skill tier, but much lower than your potential tier (where you could end up after dedication and self-improvement). 

Let's take MadMan's example. Let's assume you're Silver 1 and you're constantly matched with Silver 4 players. Let's also assume that you all belong in your respective tiers. You want to improve and climb, but you're finding it really hard. Why? Because while you may not play at a gold level yet, it's drastically harder to improve your own gameplay when you're playing in an elo lower than your own because chances are there aren't very many players who will punish your mistakes the way that a gold 5+ player would. 
You don't have to do anything special to do well vs a lower elo player, that's why you're where you are. But at the same time, you're not high enough skill level to actively carry your team, much less if you're on a team that refuses to work together or makes the game unnecessarily harder (int, afk, *highly* toxic to the point where they tilt others, etc). But **how can you improve when you're only going against players who are worse than you?**"

That's what elo hell is. It's being "too good" to get a meaningful challenge from your games, but not good enough to compensate for the disadvantages you're queued into (high death ally lanes, int, afk, etc). 

That isn't to say that you can't improve in this "rut zone" so to speak. You can work on cs'ing, roaming, grouping, objective control, managing your own lane (a bit harder bot lane as solo), etc. But at the same time, you won't be able to improve in the same capacity as if you were constantly playing against people at your own skill level or higher.

Speaking personally, the largest magnitude of improvement to my gameplay was in late season 3 when I started Ranked and early season 4 when I took it seriously. I climbed straight from bronze to gold and maintained a relatively nice win rate. Most games were either against other golds or plats lanes where I was actively punished for mistakes like overextending or not itemizing against the enemy comp to the point where I took it to heart, and learned from my mistakes. From there I spent the next two and half seasons playing mostly normals with my bronze and silver friends. Had good times, but also racked up a bunch of terrible habits because there was no one to punish me. I could do these things and get away with them, so I eventually starting doing them more often. Fast forward to season 7 where they reintroduced solo/duo Q and I decided I wanted to start actively climbing again but it feels almost impossible because of the awkward area I'm in. I go 8-2 in placements, place Silver 3. Dominate my games and skip S2 going straight to Silver 1 after series. From there it was hell. My games leading up to promos are mildly engaging at best, a dirt stomp (easy) at worse. Soon as I get into promos the teams go from low-high silver to gold/plat/diamond and I'm heavily punished for every little move to the point where I get flat out shitted on. I 0-3 my placements, and the games go right back to being really easy until I get to promos and lose them again. Some were to afk/ints, but the majority were just me flat out sucking in comparison. My winrate tanks from 87*-90% to like 51-67% and my MMR tanks to a point of stagnation (into the rut zone), and I just kinda shoot craps until I'm lucky enough to break into gold where I'm actively challenged enough to begin improving at a decent pace again. I finally hit gold in Flex (cause I wanted the double Gold +rewards), and now I'm going through the exact same thing in Solo/Duo. 

It feels like shit from start to finish. At some point I was Gold 1 in plat promos (games 4 and 5 both had at least one afk), but now I'm struggling through Silver 1, wondering if I was ever really better than this.

Yes, it's true that some games are just impossible to carry.
But the thing is, the enemy team is (in average) just as stupid as your teammates. That means (in average) you will have 4 bonobos in your team, they will have 5. Assuming that you aren't the bonobo yourself, of course.

That means over a decent amount of games you HAVE to climb - unless you are not better than your teammates.

>But the thing is, the enemy team is (in average) just as stupid as your teammates.

But the average doesn't decide a game. The difference between the teams in a particular game does. And rarely are they close enough to each other that you as one player are the difference. The averaging out effect just means players don't go into huge streaks often. ELO hell isn't where you get the worst team every time and drop a bunch of tiers. It's where you go nowhere in the long run, but most games feel like stomps, one way or the other.

It's especially bad wherever lots of people are currently being placed who don't distinguish themselves one way or another in placements. The system can't tell the difference between a player who deserves bronze 1 and a player who deserves gold 3 very well at all in just 10 games. It tends to place them both around the same rank, so games around there suck. Where most people get placed shifts over time as the season goes on (typically slowly rising over the year), but there's always a clumping area slightly above where the real baddies are dropping to who were placed a little bit ago, and that is ELO hell headquarters.
